Award.AwardTitle: Von Neumann Algebras: Rigidity, Applications to Measurable Dynamics, and Model Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The theory of von Neumann algebras was initially developed in the 1930s and 1940s by Francis J. Murray and John von Neumann as a vast generalization of matrix algebra necessary to capture the mathematical complexities of quantum mechanics by encoding the symmetries of the quantum mechanical system in roughly the same way that matrix algebra encodes the symmetries of classical mechanics and general relativity. Over the intervening decades it has been realized that von Neumann algebras represent the symmetries of many objects studied in the physical and biological sciences, leading to applications in diverse fields such as the theory of statistical mechanics, the structure of DNA molecules, the theory of error correcting codes, and the theory of quantum information theory and quantum computing. The building blocks of these symmetries are called "factors." The main goal of the theory of von Neumann algebras is to provide an effective classification of factors to understand how symmetries arise in these various settings. One approach is through so-called rigidity, where it is shown that a small, known group of symmetries actually describes the entire, vast set of symmetries of a factor. Another direction addresses the computability of the symmetries of a factor via the ability to simulate the factor in a computer by matrix algebras, what is known as the Connes embedding problem.

The last decade has seen a rapid growth in the understanding of the structure of factors, due to the development of deformation-rigidity theory that was initiated by Sorin Popa in the early 2000s. These results and approaches have additionally had a remarkable impact on the fields of measurable dynamics of groups, descriptive set theory of Polish group actions, probability theory, as well as on geometric group theory and coarse geometry. Working to develop and expand this theory, the principal investigator's research focuses on the connections between operator algebras, geometric and measurable group theory, Lie groups, and ergodic theory, specifically through the use of geometric deformations that were first investigated in work by the principal investigator and Ionut Chifan. The principal investigator is also interested in the application of logic and model-theoretic techniques to operator algebras. The project aims to achieve the following broad objectives: (1) to continue developing a perspective from which tools from Lie groups and geometric group theory can be used to classify the structure of and to demonstrate new examples of rigidity phenomena in the context of group and measure-measure space von Neumann algebras; (2) to find applications of these techniques to measurable group theory, probability theory, and the classification of C*-algebras; (3) to further explore and develop connections between continuous model theory and von Neumann algebras, C*-algebras, and the theory of operator systems with applications to the Connes embedding problem. The principal investigator will continue to teach advanced courses and organize seminars in operator algebras, working closely with graduate students to develop and foster talent and discovery. He will also continue to broadly and actively disseminate his research through publications, seminar and colloquium talks, and conferences and workshops, at both the national and international level.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – DMS 1600857

Intellectual Merit

The project resulted in 8 papers, 6 of which have been published or accepted for publication at peer-reviewed journals. The remaining two are currently under review for publication at peer-reviewed journals.

In collaborations with Isaac Goldbring and Bradd Hart, the PI expanded the use of techniques from the first-order model theory of metric structures in operator algebras. This included giving a first-order treatment for bimodules associated to von Neumann algebras, finding bounds on the logical complexity of expressing various finite-dimensional approximation properties for C*-algebras, and using model-theoretic forcing to investigate several outstanding conjectures on matrix approximations of C*-algebras.

With Rolando de Santiago, Ben Hayes, and Daniel J Hoff, the PI demonstrated the existence of maximal subalgebras of tracial von Neumann algebras with respect to the class of “s-malleable” deformations first studied in breakthrough work of Sorin Popa. This led to new structural results for tracial von Neumann algebras constructed from groups making progress towards several open conjectures in the field.

With Ben Hayes, David Jekel, and Brent Nelson, the PI developed the use of strong random matrix approximations to give new proofs of several results around Popa’s foundational work on the maximal amenability of maximal abelian generator subalgebras of free group factors.

Broader Impacts

The project provided for the instruction and training of two undergraduate researchers. This amounted to supervised original research resulting in a publication co-authored with the PI, experience in preparing those results for publication, experience in disseminating these results at several undergraduate research conferences and poster events, and experience in scientific computing and use of data clusters for computational processing.

At the graduate level, the PI is currently advising two graduate students both of whom are working on completing thesis projects. In the last year the PI has also taken a role in mentoring two graduate students in physics, conducting reading courses in operator algebras and the mathematical aspects of quantum information theory.

The PI served as postdoctoral mentor for one postdoc, Meng-Che “Turbo” Ho, who has received an MSRI postdoctoral fellowship and will be a tenure-track assistant professor of mathematics at Cal State Northridge beginning January 2021.

Since the start of the grant the PI has been involved in organizing six conferences and workshops. This has included a week-long workshop “Classification of Group von Neumann Algebras” which was held at American Institute of Mathematics in 2018 and a three-day workshop on quantitative linear algebra and operator systems, “QIT meets QLA” in November 2019. The PI has been an active member of regional research communities, which has included helping to organize the quarterly Wabash Modern Analysis Seminar meetings and the semiannual meetings of the Geometry, Groups, and Dynamics seminars.

The PI has traveled extensively giving research talks and disseminating the results obtained during the grant, including departmental colloquia at UC Irvine, Texas A&M, and Indiana University and a mini-course in C*-algebras at the workshop “Model Theory of Operator Algebras” held at UC Irvine.
